en:
A seated (?) figure, perhaps Dionysos (only part of left arm [?] and diagonal thyrsos, remaining); Demeter, seated 3/4-view to the left on a cista (?), with her head profile to the right, wearing a peplos belted high over a long overfold, with two vertical striations (relief) down the front of her garment, a himation draped over her lower body, a polos with vegetal ornament, pendant earrings, a single band necklace with a central pendant, a beaded bracelet on her right hand, and a band bracelet on her left hand, leans her bent left arm on the back of her seat (the back is not visible), and holds a scepter in her upraised right hand; three stalks of grain; a white, nude boy, Ploutos, standing 3/4-view to the right, with his head turned 3/4-view to the left, and his weight on his left leg, with his right leg relaxed, wearing a grain crown, with a colored (or white?) himation, draped over his bent left arm, holds in both hands, slightly to the right, a gold keras filled with grain stalks; a white female figure, probably Kore (only right body preserved), standing near frontal, with her weight on her left leg, and her right leg relaxed, wearing a white (?), patterned himation with gilded relief border, probably over a chiton, and a band on her right wrist, bends her right arm above Ploutos.

According to Clinton (50) this Ploutos is a perfect parallel to the boy on the Great Eleusinian relief (Athens, NM 126), except for the keras, which, "... however, .. is not an essential attribute of Eleusinian Ploutos. The crucial element is the display of grain." In this painted representation, however, we can be more confident that Ploutos rather than Triptolemos is intended.

<bibl>LIMC</bibl>, 7.416 s.v. Ploutos no. 6 (K. Clinton);
      <bibl>Clinton 1992</bibl>, 50, 83, 93-94, 103-104, 133 no. 5 fig. 3;
      <bibl>LIMC</bibl>, 4.877 s.v. Demeter no. 402, pl. 592 (L. Beschi);
      <bibl>Mtzger 1965</bibl>, 37 no. 17, pl. 16.2.
